The lateral margin of the prezygapophysis is connected with the anterior margin of the base of the neural spine by a thick, medially curved ridge, as occurs in the anterior caudal vertebrae of position B. This ridge also defines a shallow and transversely broad prespinal fossa (figure 32: prsf). The presence of a postspinal fossa cannot be determined in any of the specimens because of breakage. The main portion of the neural spine is placed on the posterior half of the neural arch. The anterior surface of the main portion of the neural spine is anteroventrally-to-posterodorsally oriented and possesses three thin ridges, one median and two that are anteromedially oriented. These three ridges define a pair of transversely concave surfaces. The median ridge is connected with the anterior portion of the neural spine, which consists of a flange-like spur with an anterodorsally oriented dorsal margin in lateral view (figure 32a,b: asp), resembling the condition in Proterosuchus yuani (IVPP V4067) and Proterosuchus alexanderi (NMQR 1484). By contrast, this anterior spur is absent in the middle caudal vertebra of Sarmatosuchus otschevi (PIN 2865/68-25; figure 33d), the middle and posterior caudal vertebrae of Garjainia prima (PIN 951/65), and Erythrosuchus africanus (NHMUK PV R3592; figure 33a). In the referred specimen of Samsarasuchus pamelae, there is a shallow, concave longitudinal depression adjacent to the base of the anterior spur of the neural spine.

This position is represented by ISIR 1120, which lacks most of the right prezygapophysis, both postzygapophyses and the posterior end (main part) of the neural spine (figure 32g− l and table 12). Only those characters that differ from or cannot be determined in the middle caudal vertebrae of position A are described here. The neurocentral suture is also closed.

The centrum is 1.91 times longer than its anterior height, resembling the condition in the middle caudal vertebra of Sarmatosuchus otschevi (1.88: PIN 2865/68-25; figure 33d), Cuyosuchus huenei (1.76: MCNAM PV 2669), and a specimen referred to Chasmatosuchus rossicus (2.0: PIN 2252/383; [40]; figure 33b). By contrast, the preserved middle caudal vertebrae of Garjainia prima and Erythrosuchus africanus have ratios less than 1.25 (PIN 951/65; [146]; figure 33a). Both anterior and posterior articular surfaces of the centrum are slightly dorsoventrally taller than broad and possess a notochordal pit. The ventral surface of the centrum is flat and separated from the lateral surfaces by a distinct change in slope that forms a sharp longitudinal edge along the ventrolateral surface of the centrum (figure 32l: led), contrasting with the continuously transversely convex ventral surface of the centrum of Sarmatosuchus otschevi (PIN 2865/68-25; figure 33e). The prezygapophysis is relatively short, being anteriorly extended slightly beyond the level of the anterior margin of the centrum (figure 32h). The ridges collateral to the anterior spur of the neural spine that are present in GSI 2119 are absent in ISIR 1120. The anterior spur of the neural spine of ISIR 1120 (figure 32g ,h: asp) is considerably lower than that of GSI 2119.

Position C. This region of the middle caudal series is represented by GSI 2124 (Huxley [57]: plate III, fig. 5; figure 32s and table 12) and GSI 2125 (Huxley [57]: plate III, fig. 6; figure 32m–r). GSI 2124 currently lacks most of its neural arch, but it seems that at least the prezygapophyses were originally more complete. GSI 2125 lacks most of the left transverse process and most of the right postzygapophysis, the right side of the centrum and base of neural arch, and the anterior and posterior surfaces of the centrum and distal end of the neural spine are damaged. These two vertebrae are described together because of their consistent morphology. Only those characteristics that differ from or cannot be determined in the middle caudal vertebrae of positions A and B are described. The neurocentral suture is closed in both specimens.

The centrum is 1.74 times longer than its anterior height in GSI 2124. The ventral surface of the centrum possesses the same morphology as in ISIR 1120. The facets for the haemal arches are poorly developed and not subdivided. The prezygapophysis is almost horizontal and its base is not connected to the neural spine. The prespinal fossa is reduced to a deep, subcircular opening. The postspinal fossa is absent. These features of the neural arch may indicate that GSI 2125 is a more posterior vertebra than GSI 2119. The anterior margin of the neural spine is continuously concave in lateral view and finishes anteriorly between both prezygapophyses. There is no anterior spur and the posterior surface of the neural spine possesses a sharp edge (figure 32 m,o).

This region of the tail is represented by five vertebrae. GSI 2126 (Huxley [57]: plate III, fig. 7; figure 34a−e and table 12) lacks the right prezygapophysis, both postzygapophyses, and most of the left prezygapophysis. The distal end of the neural spine is damaged. ISIR 1123 lacks the zygapophyses and the distal end of the neural spine (figure 34f− k and table 12). ISIR 1121 lacks most of the neural arch (figure 34l −o and table 12) and ISIR 1122 lacks the zygapophyses, the anteroventral end of the centrum, and the posterior end of the centrum, and the distal margin of the neural spine is damaged (figure 34p− s). PGRU/GL/M/VF-003 is almost complete, lacking the distal end of the neural spine and having some damage on the tip of the zygapophyses and anterior and posterior margins of the centrum [46].

The centrum is 2.49 times longer than its anterior height in GSI 2126, 2.69 times in ISIR 1121, and ca. 2.25 in PGRU/GL/M/VF-003, being considerably more elongated than the middle caudal vertebrae. These ratios resemble those of the posterior caudal vertebrae of the ‘Arcadia proterosuchian’ (2.34: QMF9536; 3.00: QMF9537) and Proterosuchus yuani (2.15: IVPP V2719). By contrast, as occurs in other regions of the vertebral column, the posterior caudal vertebrae of Erythrosuchus africanus are proportionally shorter (1.53: NHMUK PV R3592). The anterior and posterior articular surfaces of the centrum are placed at the same dorsoventral level and are concave. These surfaces are slightly dorsoventrally taller than broad in GSI 2126 and PGRU/GL/M/VF-003, and the opposite is the case in ISIR 1121. Both surfaces possess a centrally placed notochordal pit. The centrum is slightly constricted transversely at mid-length. The ventral surface of the centrum is mainly flat and separated from the dorsoventrally convex lateral surface by a longitudinal change in slope in GSI 2126 (figure 34k), ISIR 1121 (figure 34m), and PGRU/GL/M/VF-003, resembling the condition in the ‘Arcadia proterosuchian’ (QMF9536, 9537), but in the latter specimens the median surface between the changes in slope is transversely concave. By contrast, ISIR 1122 possesses a low and sharp median ventral keel (figure 34r: vk), as occurs in a posterior caudal vertebra of Proterosuchus yuani (IVPP V2719). The facets for articulation with the haemal arch are low. The neurocentral suture is closed in all the specimens. The transverse process is strongly reduced or absent. When the transverse process is absent there is instead a horizontal, rugose ridge positioned level with the dorsal margin of the centrum (figure 34: tp, ri). The base of the prezygapophysis is mainly parallel to the sagittal axis and slightly anterodorsally oriented in lateral view (PGRU/GL/M/VF-003). There is a thin ridge that extends posteriorly from the base of the prezygapophysis along the lateral surface of the neural arch in ISIR 1123. This ridge finishes before reaching the base of the postzygapophysis and is absent in ISIR 1122, but is present in the ‘Arcadia proterosuchian’ (QMF9536, 9537). The neural spine is very narrow and low along its entire preserved length. The dorsal margin is concave in lateral view and the highest point of the spine is placed at its posterior end. PGRU/GL/M/VF-003 possesses a low and rounded spur on the anterior region of the neural spine.

The presence of intercentra cannot be determined in Samsarasuchus pamelae because the axial elements are preserved in isolation. However, in one second sacral vertebra there is an intercentrum fused to the anteroventral margin of its centrum (NHMUK PV R37579; figure 27a,d–f : int). There is no trace of separation between the intercentrum and centrum in this specimen, but the identification of the former is based on its shape and anterior extension distinctly beyond the anterior margin of the centrum. The intercentrum is oval in ventral view, with a transverse main axis, and crescent-shaped in anterior view, with a transversely convex ventral surface (figure 27a).

The humerus is represented by one complete (ISIR 1128; figure 35 a–i and table 13) and one partial (ISIR 1127; figure 35j ,h and table 13) left humeri, a partial proximal half of a right humerus (ISIR 1129), and a distal half of a left humerus (PGRU/GL/M/VF-001; [46]). Only some portions of the medial edge of the proximal end present some damage in (ISIR 1128). ISIR 1127 lacks most of the deltopectoral crest and the distal surface of the bone is damaged. ISIR 1129 lacks most of the deltopectoral crest and the proximal surface is damaged. The four specimens possess a consistent morphology. ISIR 1128 is approximately 30% bigger than ISIR 1127 and the muscle scars of the former specimen are more developed. PGRU/GL/M/VF-001 has a size intermediate between the latter two specimens.

The proximal and distal ends of the humerus are strongly transversely expanded, being subequal in transverse width in the smaller specimen (ISIR 1127) and the distal end proportionally more expanded in the larger specimen (ISIR 1128). In ISIR 1128, the proximal and distal widths represent 0.48 and 0.51 times the total length of the bone, respectively. The ratio of proximal expansion closely resembles that of Proterosuchus yuani (0.48: IVPP V2719, 0.50: IVPP V4067) and is lower in Cuyosuchus huenei (0.41: MCNAM 2669). By contrast, the proximal end of the humerus is considerably more transversely expanded in erythrosuchids (e.g. Erythrosuchus africanus: 0.70: SAM-PK-905; Garjainia prima: 0.57: 951/36-1; Garjainia madiba: 0.63: BP/1/5360; Shansisuchus shansisuchus: 0.58–0.62: Young [153]: table 7). The proximal end is symmetrically expanded transversely, whereas the entepicondyle is slightly more expanded than the ectepicondyle on the distal end of the bone. The main axis of the proximal end is rotated approximately 48º with respect to the main axis of the distal end in the two more complete specimens (figure 35), closely resembling the condition in Proterosuchus yuani (IVPP V2719; figure 36c ,h), whereas a higher degree of torsion (ca. 70° or higher) is present in Prolacerta broomi (BP/1/2675; figure 36a,f), Tasmaniosaurus triassicus (UTGD 54655: tibia B of Ezcurra [148], here reinterpreted as a left humerus, see Discussion; figure 36g), and Antarctanax shackletoni ([160]; figure 36b). By contrast, the main axes of the proximal and distal ends of the humerus of Cuyosuchus huenei (MCNAM PV 2669) and erythrosuchids (e.g. Guchengosuchus shiguaiensis: [161]; Erythrosuchus africanus: [146]; Garjainia prima: [152]; figure 36d,i) are sub-parallel to each other. The humerus is crescent-shaped in proximal view, with a continuously concave ventral margin (figure 35g). The dorsal margin of the proximal end is convex on its medial half and laterally becomes shallowly concave. The proximal articular surface of the bone is rugose and possesses a shallow longitudinal depression along its entire extension. This depression is deeper in the smaller individual (ISIR 1127), probably because of a lower degree of ossification. The internal tuberosity is not offset from the proximal margin of the bone and is situated distal to the point at which the deltopectoral crest merges with the proximal articular surface (figure 35b,c: it). The dorsolateral corner of the humerus is continuously convex in proximal view, as occurs in Cuyosuchus huenei (MCNAM PV 2669), Garjainia prima (Maidment et al., 2020), Erythrosuchus africanus (SAM-PK-905), and Shansisuchus shansisuchus [153]. By contrast, the humerus of Proterosuchus yuani possesses a large, subtriangular and dorsolaterally oriented projection on this region of the bone (IVPP V2719).

The deltopectoral crest of referred specimens of Samsarasuchus pamelae extends along 45% of the total length of the bone in the larger specimen (ISIR 1128; figure 35a –c,f,g: dpc) and approximately 40% in the smaller one (ISIR 1127; figure 35h: dpc), resembling the condition in other early archosauriforms (e.g. Proterosuchus yuani: 37%: IVPP V2719, 42%: IVPP V4067; Cuyosuchus huenei: 48%: Rusconi [159]: fig. 38c; Garjainia prima: 48%: PIN 951/36-1; Garjainia madiba: 43%: BP/1/5360; Shansisuchus shansisuchus: 40–48%: Young [153]: table 7). By contrast, the deltopectoral crest is more distally extended along the shaft in Erythrosuchus africanus (55%: SAM-PK-905). The deltopectoral crest is mainly ventrally oriented in the preserved referred specimens of Samsarasuchus pamelae. The base of the deltopectoral crest possesses a slight medial bowing and, as a result, its lateral surface is shallowly concave, as occurs in other early archosauriforms (e.g. Antarctanax shackletoni: [160]; Proterosuchus yuani: IVPP V2719; Garjainia prima: [152]; Erythrosuchus africanus: SAM-PK-905). This concave lateral surface has a distinct muscle insertion area, probably homologous to the insertion area of the M. deltoideus clavicularis of extant crocodiles ([162]; figure 35f: M.dcl). This surface extends onto the dorsolateral surface of the bone as a massive muscle scar and reaches proximally the margin of the proximal articular surface of the bone. This scar probably represents the area of origin of the M. triceps brevis ([152]; figure 35 f: M.trb). The distal margin of the deltopectoral crest possesses a thick tuberosity that finishes at the apex of the process as a flat, proximoventrally facing surface, resembling the condition in several non-eucrocopodan archosauromorphs [18]. Immediately proximal to the apex of the deltopectoral crest, there are several deep pits and ridges. This surface is the insertion area of the M. supracoracoideus complex and, more proximally, the M. coracobrachialis brevis dorsalis in extant crocodiles ([162]; figure 35a,g: M.sco). The medial surface of the deltopectoral crest is proximodistally concave proximally and becomes convex distally, along the surface of the tuberosity. The latter surface possesses a distinct muscle scar formed by thin striations, on which inserts the M. pectoralis in extant crocodiles ([162]; figure 35b: M.pec). The base of the deltopectoral crest and the dorsal surface of the proximal end of the bone are separated by a sharp change in slope, which is more angled in the smaller specimen. Along this change in slope, there is a striated surface that reaches proximally the articular surface of the bone and probably represents proximally the insertion area of the M. scapulohumeralis caudalis proximally and distally the insertion of the M. latissimus dorsi ([152]; figure 35e,f: M.shc, M.lad). The ventromedial corner of the proximal end of the humerus is slightly striated, probably indicating the insertion area of the Mm. subcoracoideus and subscapularis ([152]; figure 35b: M.sbc+sbs).

The maximum constriction of the shaft occurs close to its mid-length and at this point the cross-section is oval with a transverse main axis. The ventral surface of the distal end possesses a shallowly concave depression that separates the entepicondyle from the ectepicondyle. The dorsal surface possesses a more shallowly concave and proximally extended surface that separates both distal regions, which probably represents the origin area of the M. brachialis ([163]; figure 35e: M.br). Along the transition between this concave surface and the distal articular surface of the bone there is a series of moderately large pits aligned mainly in a single row. These pits may be related to the attachment of the articular capsule of the elbow. The ventrolateral surface of the distal end possesses a thick supinator process that delimits anteriorly a shallow ectepicondylar groove (figure 35a,d ,e,f,h: spr, engr). There is no ectepincondylar foramen, resembling the condition of most other archosauromorphs [18], but contrasting with the notch-shaped, partially closed opening of Proterosuchus yuani (IVPP V2719, V4067; figure 36 c,h: not). The ectepicondyle is more dorsally expanded than the entepicondyle as a result of the presence of a very thick tuberosity that runs along the dorsolateral surface of the distal half of the bone and reaches the distal margin. The entepicondyle (figure 35: entc) is moderately well developed medially, resembling the condition in Tasmaniosaurus triassicus (UTGD 54655; figure 36g) and the vast majority of early archosauriforms (e.g. Antarctanax shackletoni: [160]; Cuyosuchus huenei: MCNAM PV 2669; Guchengosuchus shiguaiensis: [161]; Garjainia prima: [152]; Erythrosuchus africanus: SAM-PK-905; figure 36b,d ,i). However, the entepicondyle is considerably more abruptly projected from the shaft, forming an angle of >45° with respect to the longitudinal axis of the shaft in dorsal or ventral views, in the proterosuchids Proterosuchus alexanderi (NMQR 1484; figure 36 e,j) and Proterosuchus yuani (IVPP V2719, V4067; figure 36c,h). In ventral view, the entepicondyle and ectepicondyle are subequally distally developed, as in Proterosuchus alexanderi (NMQR 1484; figure 36e), Proterosuchus yuani (IVPP V2719, V4067; figure 36c ), Antarctanax shackletoni ([160]; figure 36b), but the entepicondyle is distinctly more distally projected than the ectepicondyle in Tasmaniosaurus triassicus (UTGD 54655; figure 36g), Cuyosuchus huenei (MCNAM PV 2669), and erythrosuchids (e.g. Guchengosuchus shiguaiensis: [161]; Garjainia prima: [152]; Erythrosuchus africanus: SAM-PK-905). The dorsal surface of the entepicondyle possesses a muscle scar composed of thick striations and may represent the origin area of the flexor musculature [163]. The distal articular surface of the bone is well ossified and very rugose, indicating the presence of a cartilaginous capping. There is a broadly transversely concave surface that separates the two distal condyles. The distal surface of the entepicondyle is formed by two transversely flat surfaces that meet in a right-angled change of slope that produced a distally projected apex. The surface of the ectepicondyle is continuously dorsoventrally convex. There are no distinct ulnar and radial condyles (= capitellum and trochlea), as occurs in most other early crocopods [18].

The pelvic region is represented by a left partial ilium originally reported by Satsangi [45] (GSI 18125; figure 37e− i and table 14) and a cast of a fairly complete left ilium (NHMUK PV R10149; figure 37a− d and table 14). GSI 18125 lacks most of the postacetabular process and the dorsal margin of the iliac blade is damaged, whereas NHMUK PV R10149 only lacks a small portion of the anterodorsal corner of the iliac blade. The original specimen of NHMUK PV R10149 could not be located during this study and does not represent a cast of GSI 18125 before any potential breakage as there are minor differences in their morphology and the latter is a smaller specimen. Both ilia possess a consistent morphology between each other and are described together.

The lateral surface of the preacetabular process and the portion of the iliac blade dorsal to the supraacetabular crest are mostly flat. A series of thin, parallel striations are present adjacent to the anterior, dorsal, and posterior margins of the iliac blade. These striations converge towards the dorsal margin of the acetabulum but they do not reach it. These striations probably represent the origin areas of the Mm. iliotibialis ([152]; figure 37a,e: Mm.itb). The preacetabular process is anteriorly short and semi-circular in lateral view (figure 37a,e : prap), resembling the condition in Proterosuchus alexanderi (NMQR 1484; figure 38 b,c: prap), Proterosuchus yuani (IVPP V4067; figure 38a: prap), and Garjainia prima [152]. By contrast, Cuyosuchus huenei [159], Erythrosuchus africanus [146], and Shansisuchus shansisuchus [153] have a sub-triangular preacetabular process with a distinct anterior apex in lateral or medial views. The preacetabular process of the referred specimens of Samsarasuchus pamelae curves slightly medially towards its anterior tip (figure 37 c,h: prap), resembling the condition in Cuyosuchus huenei [159], Garjainia prima (PIN 951/8-1), Erythrosuchus africanus (NHMUK PV R3592), and Proterosuchus alexanderi (NMQR 1484), but this condition occurs more conspicuously in the latter species. By contrast, the preacetabular process is mostly straight in Proterosuchus yuani (IVPP V4067) in dorsal view. The central region of the iliac blade, immediately dorsal to the supraacetabular crest, is slightly inflated, rugose and pitted, probably indicating the origin area of the M. iliofemoralis ([152]; figure 37a: M.ifm).

The postacetabular process is subtriangular, with a tapering posterior end, and is mainly posteriorly oriented (figure 37a,b: poap), as occurs in Proterosuchus alexanderi (NMQR 1484; figure 38c: poap). Erythrosuchus africanus and Shansisuchus shansisuchus also have a tapering postacetabular process, but with a more rounded posterior tip [146,153], but the postacetabular process is more sub-rectangular in Garjainia prima [152], Garjainia madiba [142], and Cuyosuchus huenei [159]. The lateral surface of the postacetabular process of the referred specimen of Samsarasuchus pamelae is dorsoventrally convex, contrasting with the flat anterior half of the iliac blade. This convex surface has anteroventrally-to-posterodorsally oriented striations that probably indicate the origin site of the M. iliofibularis ([152]; figure 37a: M.ifb). The length of the postacetabular process is 0.92 times the length of the acetabulum, closely resembling the ratio in Proterosuchus yuani (ca. 0.92: Young [133]: fig. 10), Cuyosuchus huenei (0.91: Rusconi [159]: fig. 31a), Garjainia prima (0.98: PIN 951/8-1), and Erythrosuchus africanus (0.87: NHMUK PV R3592; 0.90: SAM-PK-905). The postacetabular process is distinctly longer in Garjainia madiba (1.19: BP/1/5525) and Shansisuchus shansisuchus (1.34: Young [153]: fig. 30b) than in Samsarasuchus pamelae. The dorsoventral axis of the postacetabular process possesses a slight lateral torsion towards the posterior end of the structure. As a result, the lateral surface of the posterior portion of the process faces slightly ventrally. The ventral portion of the base of the postacetabular process, immediately dorsal to the base of the ischiadic peduncle, possesses a semilunar groove with a dorsoventral main axis on its lateral surface (figure 37a: slgr). This depressed surface may be associated to the origin of the M. caudofemoralis brevis [152].

The iliac acetabular wall is ventrally developed as a subtriangular projection with continuous and transversely thick pubic and ischial articular surfaces on its ventral margin, which indicates the presence of a fully closed acetabulum (figure 37: aw, f.isq, f.pu). The lateral surface of the acetabular wall is gently concave and possesses a distinct and anteroposteriorly extended surface restricted to approximately the ventral half of the acetabulum. This surface possesses a distinct “zigzag”-shaped dorsal margin that probably indicates the dorsal limit of the hyaline cartilage [164]. The supraacetabular crest is restricted to the anterodorsal corner of the acetabulum, straight, and ends abruptly posteriorly as a thick, rounded structure (figure 37a ,e: sac), as occurs in Proterosuchus alexanderi (NMQR 1484; figure 38b: sac), Proterosuchus yuani (IVPP V4067; figure 38a: sac), and a specimen referred to Vonhuenia friedrichi (PIN 1025/406; [40]; figure 38d: sac). The supraacetabular crest of erythrosuchids (e.g. Garjainia prima: [152]; Erythrosuchus africanus: [146]; Shansisuchus shansisuchus: [153]; Bharitalasuchus tapani: [100]) also ends abruptly posteriorly, but it bows distinctly dorsally. In addition, Shansisuchus shansisuchus and Bharitalasuchus tapani differ from the above-mentioned taxa in the presence of a supraacetabular crest that curves posteroventrally to frame the posterodorsal corner of the acetabulum [100]. The supraacetabular crest of the referred ilia of Samsarasuchus pamelae is poorly laterally developed and its lateralmost projection occurs immediately posterior to the mid-length of the acetabulum.

The pubic peduncle is moderately long and oriented at an angle of ca. 43° and ca. 50º with respect to the anteroposterior plane in the two available specimens, respectively. The distal end of the pubic peduncle is slightly anteroposteriorly expanded in lateral view and possesses a semi-circular articular facet, with a convex anterior margin. The anterior margin of the pubic peduncle is straight in lateral view. The ischiadic peduncle (figure 37a ,e: isp) is shorter than the pubic peduncle and lacks a well-rimmed antitrochanter, as is also the case in other non-archosaurian archosauriforms [18]. The ischiadic peduncle is posterolaterally oriented in ventral view and strongly laterally projected (figure 37 d,i: f.isq). As a result, the ischiadic peduncle extends more laterally than the supraacetabular crest, as occurs in Proterosuchus alexanderi (NMQR 1484). By contrast, the ischiadic peduncle is approximately aligned to the sagittal plane or slightly posterolaterally oriented in ventral view in erythrosuchids (e.g. Garjainia prima: PIN 951/8; Erythrosuchus africanus: NHMUK PV R3592; Bharitalasuchus tapani: [100]). The distal end of the ischiadic peduncle is poorly posteriorly projected, resembling the condition in the referred specimen of Vonhuenia friedrichi (PIN 1025/406; figure 38d: isp), other proterosuchids (e.g. Proterosuchus alexanderi: NMQR 1484; Proterosuchus yuani: Young [133]: fig. 10), and Cuyosuchus huenei (Rusconi [159]: fig. 31). By contrast, Garjainia prima [152], Garjainia madiba [142], and Erythrosuchus africanus [146] have a strongly posteriorly projected distal end of the ischiadic peduncle, forming a distinct heel, whereas in Shansisuchus shansisuchus (Young [153]: figs. 29, 30) and Bharitalasuchus tapani [100] the ischiadic peduncle is posteroventrally oriented along its entire length. The distal articular surface of the ischiadic peduncle is flat, but possesses a few, broad striations. This articular surface is subtriangular, with a posterolaterally oriented apex.

The medial surface of the iliac blade possesses two distinct facets for articulation with the sacral ribs. The facet for the first primordial sacral has an inverted L-shaped contour, with an anteroposteriorly oriented main axis and its most depressed area situated anteroventrally (figure 37 b,f: f.S1), resembling the condition in other early archosauriforms (e.g. Garjainia prima: [152]). This facet is delimited anteroventrally by a low ridge that merges anterodorsally with the base of the preacetabular process. The facet for the second primordial sacral rib is crescent-shaped, with a convex anterodorsal margin (figure 37b,f: f.S2). The ventral portion of this facet is positioned at the base of the ischiadic peduncle and extends dorsally onto the anteroventral region of the base of the postacetabular process, as occurs in other early archosauriforms (e.g. referred specimen of Vonhuenia friedrichi: PIN 1025/406; Garjainia prima: [152]; Erythrosuchus africanus: [146]). The posterior end of the facet for the second primordial sacral rib tapers strongly along the ventromedial egde of the postacetabular process and finishes approximately at the mid-length of the process, as is the case in Proterosuchus alexanderi (figure 38c: f.S2). A longitudinal, slightly posterodorsally slanting, ridge separates both facets along the base of the postacetabular process and part of the central region of the iliac wall. The surfaces of the facets for the sacral ribs are finely striated. The medial surface of the acetabular wall is flat, with a posteroventrally-to-anterodorsally oriented low and rounded tuberosity situated at the level of the posterior margin of the acetabulum, as occurs in the referred specimen of Vonhuenia friedrichi (PIN 1025/406).

The posterior autopodium is represented by the distal end of a fourth metatarsal (ISIR 1130; figure 39a− d,f,g and table 15) and an ungual pahalanx (ISIR 1131; figure 39i− m and table 15). The morphology of these bones closely resembles those of the foot of Proterosuchus fergusi (SAM-PK-K140) and Proterosuchus yuani (IVPP V2719; figure 39e). The distal end of the metatarsal is 1.5 times broader transversely than it is dorsoventrally deep and is asymmetric, with one condyle dorsoventrally lower than the other, as occurs in the fourth metatarsal of Proterosuchus fergusi (SAM-PK-K140: mtt IV ratio = 1.5). By contrast, the distal end of the metatarsal III of Proterosuchus fergusi is symmetric and the ratio between the transverse width and dorsoventral depth is lower in the second and third metatarsals (SAM-PK-K140: mtt II−III ratio = 1.3). Only the medial surface of the distal end of the fourth metatarsal possesses a collateral fossa in Proterosuchus fergusi (SAM-PK-K140) and only one side has a fossa in ISIR 1130. Thus, this line of evidence may suggest that ISIR 1130 is a left element. On the other hand, there is a very well developed tuber placed immediately proximodorsal to this collateral groove and an equivalent tuber is present on the lateral side of the metatarsals of Erythrosuchus africanus (BP/1/2096). This would indicate that ISIR 1130 is a right side element. As a consequence, we consider the assignment of ISIR 1130 to the right or left side as ambiguous. The presence of a tuber immediately proximodorsal to the distal end of the metatarsals (figure 39 a,d: tu) also occurs in Proterosuchus yuani (IVPP V2719; figure 39e: tu), but not in Proterosuchus fergusi (SAM-PK-K140). The distal end of the metatarsal referred to Samsarasuchus pamelae is symmetrically transversely expanded with respect to the shaft. The shaft is slightly transversely broader than deep where it is broken off (figure 39f). The dorsal surface of the bone lacks a distinct extensor fossa, as occurs in the metatarsals of Proterosuchus fergusi (SAM-PK-K140), Proterosuchus yuani (IVPP V2719), Garjainia prima (PIN 951), and Erythrosuchus africanus (BP/1/2096). As mentioned, the lateral surface of the bone lacks a collateral fossa and there are several thick longitudinal striations in this area. The distal articular surface possesses two condyles that are broadly separated from each other on the ventral surface but not on the distal surface (figure 39 a,b,g). Both condyles are subequally transversely broad, but the medial condyle is dorsoventrally lower than the lateral one. The medial condyle possesses a convex ventral margin in distal view, whereas the lateral condyle possesses a squared profile.

The ungual pahalanx (ISIR 1131) lacks its distal tip and closely resembles those of Proterosuchus yuani (IVPP V2719; figure 39h ), Proterosuchus fergusi (SAM-PK-K140), and Garjainia prima ([152]; figure 39n,o). In particular, when compared with the other most abundant tetrapods of the Panchet Formation, ISIR 1131 differs from dicynodont unguals (e.g. Lystrosaurus georgi: [165]) in being transversely narrower, dorsoventrally deeper, and more ventrally curved. ISIR 1131 is less ventrally curved than the manual unguals of Proterosuchus fergusi (SAM-PK-K140) and Proterosuchus yuani (IVPP V4067), but resembles the degree of curvature of the pedal unguals of these same specimens. As a result, ISIR 1131 is interpreted as a pedal ungual. ISIR 1131 is continuously ventrally curved and its most distally preserved portion extends ventrally to the level of the flexor tubercle. The dorsal surface of the claw is transversely convex and unkeeled. The ventral surface is transversely flat. These surfaces possess multiple low striations and pits, resembling the condition of the unguals of Proterosuchus yuani (IVPP V2719). The flexor tubercle is poorly ventrally developed and possesses a proximoventrally facing pit (figure 39i,j ,o: tub, pi). The latter condition closely resembles that of a pedal ungual of Garjainia prima (Maidment et al. [152]: fig. 24e−g; figure 39 n,o: tub, pi), but the tubercle is lower in Garjainia prima and Samsarasuchus otschevi. The ungual referred to Samsarasuchus pamelae is moderately transversely compressed and symmetric in dorsal view, as in other early archosauriforms (e.g. Proterosuchus yuani: IVPP V2719; Garjainia prima: [152]). A well-defined, ventrally curved collateral groove is present on each side of the claw and is confluent with the proximoventral corner of the bone (figure 39i− k: gr). As a result, the collateral groove separates the flexor tubercle from the articular surface of the bone in side views. The portion of the ungual ventral to the collateral groove is slightly more transversely expanded than the dorsal one, thus forming low collateral platforms (figure 39k), resembling the condition in Garjainia prima (Maidment et al. [152]: fig. 24e−g). The proximal articular surface is dorsoventrally concave and slightly dorsoventrally deeper than broad. There is no proximodorsal lip.

p.bold: 4.4.1. Analysis 1: results using the most inclusive hypodigms

sec.p: This analysis under equal weights recovered >500,000 most parsimonious trees (MPTs)—the maximum number of trees set to be stored in memory—of 6,615 steps, with a consistency index (CI) of 0.18262 and a retention index (RI) of 0.63982. Beyond the terminals added here, the strict consensus tree (SCT; figures 40, S1 and S2) generated from the MPTs shows a topology mostly congruent with that found by Ezcurra & Sues [98]. The only exceptions are a polytomy that include dinocephalosaurids and several tanystropheids, the position of Cuyosuchus huenei as an early diverging erythrosuchid, and the position of Sphodrosaurus pennsylvanicus as the sister taxon to the genus Proterochampsa within Proterochampsidae. As a result, the overall topology of the SCT from this analysis will not be described in detail.

The new species Samsarasuchus pamelae is recovered within a Proterosuchidae composed of additional 15 terminals: Proterosuchus fergusi, Proterosuchus alexanderi, Proterosuchus goweri, Archosaurus rossicus, Proterosuchus yuani , Vonhuenia friedrichi, Jaikosuchus magnus, Gamosaurus lozovskii, Chasmatosuchus rossicus, Tsylmosuchus spp., UNIPAMPA 271, UNIPAMPA 684, UNIPAMPA 750, FC-DPV 2641, and the Arcadia proterosuchian vertebrae (see table 16). All these proterosuchids are recovered in a large polytomy in the SCT (figure 40). The analysis optimized the following 16 character states as synapomorphies of Proterosuchidae (those states preserved in Samsarasuchus pamelae indicated with an asterisk): premaxilla with anteroposteriorly deep base of the prenarial process (character 35: 0à1); premaxilla with lateroventrally opening anterior alveoli in mature individuals (character 44: 0à1); parietal with supratemporal fossa well exposed in dorsal view and mainly dorsally or dorsolaterally facing (character 161: 1à0); parietals with median posterior projection in dorsal view (character 854: 1à0); quadrate with angle between the posterior margins of the dorsal and ventral ends of 143°−158º (character 177*: 2à3); basioccipital with ventrally projected basal tubera that are parallel to each other (character 233 0à1); basioccipital with lateral development of the basal tubera that does not reach the level of the lateral margin of the occipital condyle (character 890: 0à1); parabasisphenoid with posterolaterally oriented basipterygoid processes (character 248: 0à1); lower jaw with narrow symphyseal space and well organized rugosities (class II of Holliday & Nesbitt [150]) (character 859*: 0à1); dentary with anterior end of the bone distinctly transversely broader than at level of or posterior to the sixth tooth position in dorsal or ventral view (character 891*: 0à1); posterior cervical, anterior dorsal, and sometimes middle dorsal vertebrae with a thick, mainly vertical tuberosity immediately ventral to the transverse process (character 319*: 0à1); dorsal vertebrae with mammillary processes of the neural spines extended up to the thirteenth presacral vertebra or beyond (character 365*: 2à3/4); middle caudal vertebrae with accessory laminar process on the anterior face of the neural spine (character 380*: 0à1); humerus with transverse width of the proximal end versus total length of the bone of 0.48−0.70 in non-early juvenile individuals (character 416*: 1à2); ilium with main axis of the ventral articular surface of the ischiadic peduncle posteroventrally oriented in ventral view as a result of a strong lateral projection of the peduncle, in which its lateralmost point exceeds that of the supraacetabular crest (character 908*: 0à1); and femoral proximal surface with transverse groove (character 495: 0à1).

The iterPCR protocol [166] found that the isolated basioccipital from the Permo-Triassic Buena Vista Formation of Uruguay (FC-DPV 271; [13,32]) is alternatively recovered in all possible positions within Proterosuchidae and its a posteriori pruning allows the recovery of two main groups within the clade. In this first SRCT (figures 41a and S3), one of these clades is composed of the four species of Proterosuchus and an isolated probable D4−D5 from the Lower Triassic Sanga do Cabral Formation of Brazil previously assigned to cf. Proterosuchus (UNIPAMPA 271; [110]). This group is considered here to represent the genus Proterosuchus and possesses the following five synapomorphies: posterior cervical, anterior dorsal, and sometimes anterior–middle cervical and middle–posterior dorsal vertebrae without prezygodiapophyseal lamina (character 317: 1à0); coracoid with postglenoid process tapering posteriorly in lateral view (character 403: 0à1); humerus with strongly developed entepicondyle, distinctly offset from the shaft and forming an angle <45° with respect to the longitudinal axis of the shaft (character 425: 1à2); fourth to sixth cervical vertebrae with neural spine distinctly anterodorsally canted, with the top of the neural spine anterodorsally oriented and parallel anterior and posterior margins of the neural spine in lateral view (character 767: 0à1); and tibia with proximal posterior hemicondyles separated by a distinct change in angle or shallow notch or notches in proximal view (character 810: 0à1).

Within the genus Proterosuchus, there is polytomy composed of a Proterosuchus alexanderi + Proterosuchus fergusi clade and the other members of the group. The clade formed by the former two species has three synapomorphies: antorbital fenestra length twice its height or less (character 697: 0à1); posterior cervical, anterior dorsal, and sometimes middle dorsal vertebrae without a thick, mainly vertical tuberosity immediately below the transverse process (character 319*: 1à0; represents a reversal of the plesiomorphic condition of Proterosuchidae); and third to fifth dorsal vertebrae with length versus height of centrum of 0.45–1.10 (character 351: 1à0). No further a posteriori pruning improved the resolution within Proterosuchus.

The second main clade within Proterosuchidae is composed of Vonhuenia friedrichi and a large polytomy that includes Samsarasuchus pamelae, Jaikosuchus magnus, Gamosaurus lozovskii , Chasmatosuchus rossicus, Tsylmosuchus spp., Archosaurus rossicus, an isolated cervical vertebra from the Sanga do Cabral Formation of Brazil (UNIPAMPA 750), and the Arcadia proterosuchian vertebrae (figures 41a and S3). This group is named here Chasmatosuchinae (see Systematic Palaeontology) and is supported by the following three synapomorphies (those states preserved in Samsarasuchus pamelae indicated with an asterisk): posterior cervical, anterior dorsal, and sometimes anterior-middle cervical and middle-posterior dorsal vertebrae with postzygodiapophyseal lamina (character 318: 0à1*); ninth presacral centrum with a ventral keel (character 892: 0à1*); and third to eighth or ninth presacral vertebrae with diagonal, anterodorsally-to-posteroventrally oriented ridge that reaches the base of the prezygapophysis and it is not connected to the diapophysis on the lateral surface of the neural arch (character 895: 0à1*). The number of synapomorphies of Chasmatosuchinae is limited because of the high amount of missing data in Vonhuenia friedrichi (ca. 85%). Thus, Chasmatosuchinae could have the following three additional apomorphies that are not preserved in Vonhuenia friedrichi (those states preserved in Samsarasuchus pamelae indicated with an asterisk): anterior-middle and sometimes posterior postaxial cervical vertebrae with distally restricted transverse expansion of the neural spines (not mammillary process) (character 321: 0à1*); fourth to eight presacral vertebrae with posterior expansion of the neural spine, resulting in a posterodorsally tilted posterior margin in an angle higher than 15° with respect to the anterior margin of the neural spine in lateral view (character 901: 0à1*); and anterior caudal vertebrae with surface lateral to the base of the neural spine with a very deep, laterally well defined fossa that may narrow the anterior half of the neural spine in dorsal view (character 904: 0à1*). The clade that includes all chasmatosuchines to the exclusion of Vonhuenia friedrichi has the following synapomorphies (those states preserved in Samsarasuchus pamelae indicated with an asterisk): posterior cervical, anterior and sometimes middle-posterior dorsal vertebrae with posterior centrodiapophyseal lamina (character 316: 0à1*); and fourth to sixth cervical vertebrae with strongly developed longitudinal lamina or tuberosity extended posteriorly from the base of the transverse process, flaring laterally as a prominent and thick, wing-like shelf (character 334: 0à1*).

In a second round of pruning, the iterPCR protocol found that Archosaurus rossicus acted as a wildcard within Chasmatosuchinae, being alternatively nested as sister taxon to Chasmatosuchus rossicus, Tsylmosuchus spp., Samsarasuchus pamelae, and the Arcadia proterosuchian vertebrae. The a posteriori exclusion of Archosaurus rossicus resulted in the recognition of a clade composed of Samsarasuchus pamelae and the Arcadia proterosuchian vertebrae (figure S4), which is supported by the following synapomorphy: at least some middle and posterior dorsal centra with a single keel on the ventral surface (character 353: 0à2). The third wildcard terminal identified by the iterPCR protocol is Gamosaurus lozovskii, which is alternatively found as the sister taxon to all other chasmatosuchines to the exclusion of Vonhuenia friedrichi, the sister taxon to the Samsarasuchus pamelae + the Arcadia proterosuchian vertebrae clade, and the sister taxon to the other chasmatosuchine terminals. The a posteriori pruning of Gamosaurus lozovskii recovered a clade with unresolved internal relationships that includes Jaikosuchus magnus, Chasmatosuchus rossicus , Tsylmosuchus spp., and UNIPAMPA 750 (figures 41b and S5). This clade possesses the following synapomorphy: third to fifth cervical vertebrae with maximum height of neural spine versus height of posterior articular surface of centrum of 1.40–1.90 (character 342: 3à4/5). No further a posteriori pruning improved the resolution of this clade within Chasmatosuchinae.

An isolated middle-posterior dorsal vertebra from the Sanga do Cabral Formation of Brazil (UNIPAMPA 684) is found as the earliest diverging member of Proterosuchidae in the SRCTs (figure 41a,b). UNIPAMPA 684 possesses a ventral keel and the absence of such a feature in the middle–posterior dorsal vertebrae is optimized as an apomorphy of all other, more deeply nested proterosuchids (character 875: 1à0).

The Long Reef proterosuchian is not recovered as a proterosuchid in any of the MPTs. Instead, this terminal is found in a polytomy together with Sarmatosuchus otschevi, NMQR 3570, Kalisuchus rewanensis, Antarctanax shackletoni, and a clade that includes Erythrosuchidae + Eucrocopoda (figure 40). Archosauriforms more crownward than proterosuchids possess the following synapomorphies in those trees where Antarctanax shackletoni is found as the earliest diverging member of the clade: posterior cervical, anterior dorsal, and sometimes anterior-middle cervical and middle-posterior dorsal vertebrae with postzygodiapophyseal lamina (character 318: 0à1); and fifth cervical vertebra to middle dorsal vertebrae with gradual transverse expansion of the distal half of the neural spine, but lacking distinct mammillary processes on the lateral surface of the neural spine (character 320: 2à1). By contrast, the following synapomorphy is optimized if a clade composed of Kalisuchus rewanensis + NMQR 3570 is positioned as the earliest diverging terminals of the group that includes archosauriforms more crownward than proterosuchids: cranium and lower jaw with large interdental plates close to or contacting with each other (character 1: 1à2).

The iterPCR protocol recognized that NMQR 3570 and Kalisuchus rewanensis were unstable taxa among the most immediate sister taxa to the Erythrosuchidae + Eucrocopoda clade. Their a posteriori pruning resulted in the recovery of Antarctanax shackletoni as the sister taxon to a group composed of two clades: Sarmatosuchus otschevi + the Long Reef proterosuchian and Erythrosuchidae + Eucrocopoda. Antarctanax shackletoni is placed as the sister taxon to all other archosauriforms with the exception of proterosuchids because of the presence of middle and posterior dorsal vertebrae with diapophysis level with the anteroposterior middle of the centrum (character 660: 0à1). The Long Reef proterosuchian is recovered as the sister taxon to Sarmatosuchus otschevi because of the presence of posterior cervical, anterior dorsal, and sometimes middle dorsal vertebrae with a thick, mainly vertical tuberosity immediately ventral to the transverse process (character 319: 0à1; also optimized as convergently acquired in proterosuchids), and Kalisuchus rewanensis is found as the sister taxon to NMQR 3570 because of the presence of an antorbital fenestra with a squared or slightly obtuse anteroventral corner in lateral view as a result of a sharp inflexion between the anterior and ventral margins of the opening (character 14: 0à2). Beyond these clades recovered in all the MPTs, the other relationships among these non-proterosuchid early archosauriforms are strongly variable and several of the alternative groupings are not supported by synapomorphies, e.g. the position of Kalisuchus rewanensis + NMQR 3570 as more crownward than Sarmatosuchus otschevi, the Long Reef proterosuchian and Antarctanax shackletoni; a clade composed of all these taxa to the exclusion of Antarctanax shackletoni, and the position of Kalisuchus rewanensis + NMQR 3570 as the earliest diverging members of the clade immediately more crownward to Proterosuchidae. However, the position of Antarctanax shackletoni as the earliest diverging member of the clade immediately more crownward to Proterosuchidae is found in some MPTs and supported by a synapomorphy: middle and posterior dorsal vertebrae with diapophysis level with the anteroposterior middle of the centrum (character 660: 0à1).

The Bremer supports for Proterosuchidae and the clade that includes all other archosauriforms to the exclusion of proterosuchids are 1. Similarly, the internal clades within Proterosuchidae also have minimum Bremer support values when FC-PDV 2641, Archosaurus rossicus, Gamosaurus lozovskii are excluded before calculations. However, when the more fragmentary proterosuchids (i.e. UNIPAMPA 271, UNIPAMPA 684, UNIPAMPA 750, the Arcadia proterosuchian vertebrae, and Jaikosuchus magnus) and Kalisuchus rewanensis, NMQR 3570 and the Long Reef proterosuchian are a posteriori excluded, the Bremer supports of Proterosuchidae and the genus Proterosuchus increase to 3 and that for Chasmatosuchinae is 4 (figure 41c and S6). The Bremer support is 1 among more deeply nested proterosuchid clades (i.e. Proterosuchus alexanderi + Proterosuchus fergusi and Chasmatosuchus rossicus + Tsylmosuchus spp.). In this latter calculation, the clade that includes all archosauriforms more crownward than Proterosuchidae has a Bremer support of 2. The bootstrap frequencies of Proterosuchidae are extremely low (absolute = 1%; GC = -9%), but they increase after the a posteriori pruning of fragmentary terminals. The absolute and GC bootstrap frequencies of Proterosuchidae increase to 50% and 45%, respectively (figure 41c). The absolute and GC bootstrap frequencies calculated without fragmentary terminals are 70% and 66% for the genus Proterosuchus and 65% and 51% for Chasmatosuchinae, respectively.

The analysis under implied weights with k = 10, 13 and 15 recovered 212,625 MPTs in all cases (k= 10: fit of 301.19253, CI of 0.18212 and RI of 0.63862; k = 13: fit of 255.78993, CI of 0.18226 and RI of 0.63896; k = 15: fit of 232.70435, CI of 0.18231 and RI of 0.63909). The SCTs generated from each tree set of these analyses are very similar to that obtained under equal weights (figures 42a and S7–S9). The differences are the more resolved internal relationships of the Dinocephalosauridae + Tanystropheidae clade, Proterosuchidae, Lagerpetidae and Erpetosuchidae, the position of Teyumbaita sulcognathus as sister taxon to species of the genus Hyperodapedon, Cuyosuchus huenei as one of the earliest diverging eucrocopods, Euparkeria capensis as the unambiguous sister taxon to Proterochampsia + Archosauria, Mandasuchus tanyauchen as the earliest diverging Loricata (only under k = 10), Youngosuchus sinensis as the earliest diverging member of Poposauroidea (only under k = 10), and re-arranged internal relationships of Loricata with a clade composed of Batrachotomus kupferzellensis, Luperosuchus fractus and Prestosuchus nyassicus (only under k = 10).

Regarding the internal relationships of Proterosuchidae, the SCTs show a topology congruent with that of the SRCT obtained after the a posteriori pruning of FC-DPV 2641 under equal weights, in which UNIPAMPA 684 is the sister taxon to two main clades, Proterosuchus and Chasmatosuchinae (figure 42a). FC-DPV 2641 is unambiguously recovered as a member of the genus Proterosuchus. The a posteriori pruning of UNIPAMPA 271 results in the position of Proterosuchus yuani as the sister taxon to a clade composed of FC-DPV 2641 and the three South African species of the genus Proterosuchus. This clade has two synapomorphies present in FC-DPV 2641: basioccipital with extremely short occipital neck (character 231: 0à1); and basioccipital with ventrally oriented basal tubera parallel to each other (character 233: 0à1). Within Chasmatosuchinae, the a posteriori pruning of Archosaurus rossicus and Gamosaurus lozovskii produces a topology congruent with the equivalent SRCT under equal weights but with the additional resolution of a clade composed of Chasmatosuchus rossicus and Tsylmosuchus spp. This group is supported by the presence of Cv3–Cv5 with maximum height of neural spine versus height of posterior articular surface of centrum between 1.74–3.0 (character 342: 4à5/6); contrasting with the dorsoventrally shorter neural spines of Samsarasuchus pamelae, UNIPAMPA 750 and Jaikosuchus magnus, and the condition is unknown in Vonhuenia friedrichi .

The bootstrap frequencies are very low throughout the non-erythrosuchid, non-eucrocopod archosauriform part of the trees and the highest values are for the chasmatosuchine branch that excludes Vonhuenia friedrichi (bootstrap absolute = 18% and bootstrap GC = 12% with k = 10 and 15 and boostrap absolute = 17% and bootstrap GC = 10% with k =13).

The search found >500,000 MPTs of 6,617 steps, with a CI of 0.18256 and a RI of 0.63976. The SCT tree and subsequent SRCTs are identical to those of Analysis 1 (figure S10). There is no optimized apomorphy related to the fibula referred by Ochev [109] to Jaikosuchus magnus that supports the position of the ‘Jaikosuchus Ochev hypodigm’ terminal within Proterosuchidae. The Bremer supports and bootstrap frequencies are very low throughout the non-erythrosuchid, non-eucrocopod archosauriform part of the tree.

The analysis under implied weights with k = 10, 13 and 15 recovered 212,625 MPTs in all cases (k= 10: fit of 301.28641, CI of 0.18206 and RI of 0.63856; k = 13: fit of 255.87036, CI of 0.18220 and RI of 0.63889; k = 15: fit of 232.77797, CI of 0.18226 and RI of 0.63903). The SCTs generated from these trees are identical to those of Analysis 1 under implied weights, including similarly low bootstrap frequencies for Proterosuchidae and its internal branches (figures S11–S13).

This analysis recovered >500,000 MPTs of 6,618 steps, with a CI of 0.18253 and a RI of 0.63962. The ‘Jaikosuchus + Vytshegdosuchus’ terminal is found as an aphanosaurian avemetatarsalian in all the MPTs (figure S14). Although Jaikosuchus magnus was recovered consistently as a chasmatosuchine proterosuchid in analyses 1–2, the position of the ‘Jaikosuchus + Vytshegdosuchus’ terminal within Archosauria is not completely unexpected because Vytshegdosuchus zheshartensis was found as a member of Aphanosauria in these previous analyses. The ‘Jaikosuchus + Vytshegdosuchus’ terminal has the following synapomorphies of Aphanosauria: postaxial cervical vertebrae with shallow excavation immediately lateral to the base of neural spines (character 337: 0à1); Cv3–Cv5 with maximum height of neural spine versus height of posterior articular surface of centrum between 1.40–1.68 (character 342: 2/3à4); anterior and middle postaxial cervical neural spines with an anterior overhang as a result of an anteriorly curved anterior margin of the neural spine (character 343: 0à1); and hyposphene-hypantrum present at least in one anterior-middle cervical vertebra (character 896: 2à3).

Although the topology of the SCT of Anlaysis 3 is congruent with that of analyses 1 and 2, the inclusion of the ‘Jaikosuchus + Vytshegdosuchus’ terminal produces a very large polytomy that includes multiple early archosauriform species, Erythrosuchidae, Proterochampsia, Ornithodira, and Pseudosuchia. This polytomy is not as a result of the alternative positions occupied by the ‘Jaikosuchus + Vytshegdosuchus’ terminal, but it is because inclusion of this terminal attracts two other terminals into Aphanosauria in some MPTs: Gamosaurus lozovskii and UNIPAMPA 750. These latter two terminals are also alternatively found as members of Chasmatosuchinae in other MPTs, producing the very large polytomy. The close relationship between the ‘Jaikosuchus + Vytshegdosuchus’ terminal, Gamosaurus lozovskii and UNIPAMPA 750 within Aphanosauria is supported by the following apomorphies: Cv4 or Cv5 centrum length versus height of anterior articular surface of 1.75–2.08 (character 331: 4/5à3), Cv4–Cv6 with strongly developed longitudinal lamina or tuberosity extended posteriorly from the base of the transverse process, flaring laterally as a prominent and thick, wing-like shelf (character 334: 0à1); and postaxial cervical vertebrae with a shallow, posterolaterally facing fossa on the posterior portion of the neural arch ventral to the postzygapophysis (character 335: 0à1). On the other hand, the alternative position of Gamosaurus lozovskii and UNIPAMPA 750 as chasmatosuchines is supported by the same synapomorphies listed in Analysis 1.

The a posteriori pruning of Gamosaurus lozovskii and UNIPAMPA 750 produced a SRCT identical to the equivalent consensus tree in Analysis 1. The additional pruning of FC-DPV 2641 allowed the recovery of the genus Proterosuchus and Chasmatosuchinae. However, contrasting with Analysis 1, in this case a clade including exclusively Samsarasuchus pamelae and the Arcadia proterosuchian vertebrae was not recovered. These two terminals are shown in the SRCT in a polytomy with other chasmatosuchines to the exclusion of Vonhuenia friedrichi. The branch supports are extremely low for this part of the tree, as was the case in analyses 1 and 2.

Analysis 3 under implied weights recovered 204,120 MPTs in all cases (k= 10: fit of 301.26821, CI of 0.18204 and RI of 0.63842; k = 13: fit of 255.85945, CI of 0.18217 and RI of 0.63876; k = 15: fit of 232.77050, CI of 0.18223 and RI of 0.63889). The SCTs of the analyses with the three different concavity constants have the same topology, which are almost identical topologically to those of analysis 1 and 2 under implied weights. The only difference is the position of the ‘Jaikosuchus + Vytshegdosuchus’ terminal as an aphanosaurian avemetatarsalian, as is the case in the analysis under equal weights (figures S15–S17). However, contrasting with the latter analysis, Gamosaurus lozovskii and UNIPAMPA 750 are unambiguously recovered as chasmatosuchine proterosuchids. The bootstrap frequencies are very low (<50%) among non-erythrosuchid, non-eucrocopod archosauriforms and Aphanosauria in the three analyses under implied weights.

This analysis found >500,000 MPTs of 6,617 steps, with a CI of 0.18256 and a RI of 0.63971. The SCT is almost identical to that of Analysis 1, but the ‘Kalisuchus rewanensis combined’ terminal and NMQR 3570 are recovered as proterosuchids in all the MPTs (figures 42c and S18). The iterPCR protocol shows that these two terminals are resolved as members of Chasmatosuchinae after the a posteriori pruning of FC-DPV 2641. The position of NMQR 3570 as a member of Chasmatosuchinae is supported by one synapomorphy: antorbital fenestra with squared or slightly obtuse anteroventral corner as a result of a sharp inflexion between the anterior and ventral margins of the opening in lateral view (character 14: 0à2). NMQR 3570 is positioned as the sister taxon to the ‘Kalisuchus rewanensis combined’ terminal in some MPTs, but this is not supported by any unambiguous apomorphy. The additional a posteriori pruning of NMQR 3570 and Archosaurus rossicus places the ‘Kalisuchus rewanensis combined’ as the sister taxon to Samsarasuchus pamelae. The ‘Kalisuchus rewanensis combined’ + Samsarasuchus pamelae clade has the following synapomorphy: at least some middle and posterior dorsal centra with a single keel (character 353: 0à2; condition unkown in Archosaurus rossicus). The branch supports are extremely low for this part of the tree, as was the case in previous analyses.

The analysis under implied weights with k = 10, 13 and 15 recovered 368,550 MPTs in all cases (k= 10: fit of 301.23190, CI of 0.18198 and RI of 0.63831; k = 13: fit of 255.84161, CI of 0.18212 and RI of 0.63865; k = 15: fit of 232.76103, CI of 0.18217 and RI of 0.63878). The SCTs are topologically identical in the three analyses and they show a more taxonomically inclusive Proterosuchidae than under equal weights because Sarmatosuchus otschevi and the Long Reef proterosuchian are found within it (figures 42b and S19–S21). These two terminals are recovered in a polytomy at the base of Proterosuchidae together with UNIPAMPA 271 and 684 and this position is supported by the presence of posterior cervical, anterior dorsal, and sometimes middle dorsal vertebrae with a thick, mainly vertical tuberosity immediately ventral to the transverse process (character 319*: 0à1). In addition, Antarctanax shackletoni is recovered at the base of Proterosuchidae in some MPTs, but this placement is not supported by apomorphies. In all the MPTs, UNIPAMPA 684 and the Long Reef proterosuchian form a clade, which may include or not UNIPAMPA 271 and Sarmatosuchus otschevi, and it is supported by the presenece of at least some middle and posterior dorsal centra with a single keel on the ventral surface (character 353: 0à2). This latter character state is optimized as independently acquired by Samsarasuchus pamelae and the Arcadia proterosuchian vertebrae. In some MPTs, Sarmatosuchus otshevi is found as the sister taxon to the Proterosuchus + Chasmatosuchinae clade because of the presence of middle-posterior dorsal and sometimes cervical and anterior dorsal vertebrae with hyposphene-hypantrum accessory intervertebral articulation (character 359: 0à1).

Within the genus Proterosuchus, FC-DPV 2641 is unambiguously found as a member of the clade (figure 42b), as in previous analyses under implied weights. NMQR 3570 and ‘Kalisuchus rewanensis combined’ are recovered within Chasmatosuchinae in all the MPTs (figure 42b), as it was the case in the SRCT under equal weights and the position is supported by the same apomorphy (character 14: 0à2). In the analyses under implied weights, the internal relationships of Chasmatosuchinae are completely unresolved in the SCTs, but the a posteriori pruning of NMQR 3570 and Archosaurus rossicus partially resolves this polytomy, recovering ‘Kalisuchus rewanensis combined’ as the sister taxon to Samsarasuchus pamelae. This result is congruent with that of previous analyses regarding the sister taxon relationship between the Indian proterosuchid and the Arcadia proterosuchian vertebrae. The bootstrap frequencies are very low (<50%) in the non-erythrosuchid, non-eucrocopod archosauriform region of the trees.

This analysis under equal weights recovered >500,000 MPTs of 6,615 steps, with a CI of 0.18262 and a RI of 0.64001. The SCT has a very large polytomy at the base of Archosauriformes, which is composed of all the non-erythrosuchid, non-eucrocopod archosauriforms (figure S22). The iterPCR protocol found that “Chasmatosuchus” vjushkovi is responsible for the very large polytomy at the base of Archosauriformes and its a posteriori pruning generates a SRCT that is identical to the SCT of Analysis 1 under equal weights. “Chasmatosuchus ” vjushkovi is alternatively recovered as the sister taxon to Archosauriformes, a proterosuchid outside of the Proterosuchus + Chasmatosuchinae clade, or as one of the successive sister taxa to the clade composed of Kalisuchus rewanensis + Sarmatosuchus otschevi + (Erythrosuchidae + Eucrocopoda). “Chasmatosuchus” vjushkovi shares with archosauriforms the following apomorphy: premaxilla with anteroposterior length of the main body versus its maximum dorsoventral height of 2.22–3.80 (character 28: 1à2). In the MPTs in which “ Chasmatosuchus” vjushkovi is recovered within Proterosuchidae, the exclusion of this species from the Proterosuchus + Chasmatosuchinae clade is because of the absence of a premaxilla with an anteroposteriorly deep base of the prenarial process (character 34: 0à1), and its exclusion from more crownward archosauriforms is because of the absence of a cranium or lower jaw with large interdental plates close to or contacting with each other (character 1: 0/1à2). The position of “Chasmatosuchus ” vjushkovi within Proterosuchidae or as one of the earliest branching taxa leading to Eucrocopoda is not supported by apomorphies, but by homoplasy minimization. One additional step is necessary to force the position of “Chasmatosuchus” vjushkovi within Chasmatosuchinae or its sister taxon relationship with Chasmatosuchus rossicus. The branch supports are extremely low for this part of the tree (<50%), as was the case in previous analyses.

The analysis under implied weights with k = 10, 13 and 15 recovered >500,000 MPTs in all cases (k= 10: fit of 301.19253, CI of 0.18212 and RI of 0.63881; k = 13: fit of 255.78993, CI of 0.18226 and RI of 0.63915; k = 15: fit of 232.70435, CI of 0.18231 and RI of 0.63928). The topologies of the SCTs are congruent with those under equal weights, but the relationships among non-erythrosuchid, non-eucrocopod archosauriforms are somewhat better resolved (figures 42d and S23–S25). Proterosuchidae is recognized as a clade composed of two groups, one corresponding to the genus Proterosuchus and the other to Chasmatosuchinae. The taxonomic content of these clades is the same as in Analysis 1 under implied weights (figure 42a). “Chasmatosuchus” vjushkovi is recovered in a polytomy with Proterosuchidae, the Erythrosuchidae + Eucrocopoda clade, and the successive sister taxa to the latter clade found in previous analyses (e.g. Sarmatosuchus otschevi, Kalisuchus rewanensis , Antarctanax shackletoni). Among the MPTs, “ Chasmatosuchus” vjushkovi acquires the same alternative positions as in Analysis 4 under equal weights and the a posteriori pruning of this species allows the recovery of a SRCT identical to the SCTs of Analyses 1−4 under implied weights. The branch supports are extremely low for the non-erythrosuchid, non-eucrocopod archosauriform part of the tree (<50%).

p.bold: 4.4.6. Analysis 6: results using the less inclusive hypodigms

sec.p: This analysis recovered >500,000 MPTs of 6,615 steps, with a CI of 0.18262 and a RI of 0.63982. The SCT is topologically congruent with that of previous analyses under equal weights, but with a very large polytomy among non-pseudosuchian archosauriforms, Tasmaniosaurus triassicus, and Teyujagua paradoxa (figure S26). The iterPCR protocol found that Antarctanax shackletoni, ‘Samsarasuchus pamelae reduced’, the Arcadia proterosuchian vertebrae, the Long Reef proterosuchian, UNIPAMPA 271, 684 and 750, ‘Vonhuenia friedrichi holotype’, Tsylmosuchus spp., ‘Chasmatosuchus rossicus holotype’, Gamosaurus lozovskii, and Jaikosuchus magnus were the topologically unstable terminals. The a posteriori purning of these terminals generated a SRCT that is consistent with the results of previous analyses (figure S27). It is worth mentioning that ‘Blomosuchus georgii holotype’ is unambiguously found as a proterosuchid, in a polytomy with all the other members of the clade. In particular, ‘Samsarasuchus pamelae reduced’, the Arcadia proterosuchian vertebrae, UNIPAMPA 750, ‘Vonhuenia friedrichi holotype’, Tsylmosuchus spp., ‘Chasmatosuchus rossicus holotype’, Gamosaurus lozovskii, and Jaikosuchus magnus are included within Chasmatosuchinae and this clade is alternatively found as the sister taxon to Archosauriformes or within Erythrosuchidae. The exclusion of the chasmatosuchines from Archosauriformes is supported by the absence of following character states optimized as apomorphies of the latter clade in this analysis: length of the pectoral centra (last two cervical and first two dorsal vertebrae) versus the height of their anterior articular surface of 0.72–1.03 (character 311: 1à2), Cv4 or Cv5 centrum length versus height of anterior articular surface of 1.31–1.73 (character 331: 3à2), anterior and middle postaxial cervical neural spines without an anterior overhang (character 343: 1à0), and mammillary processes of the neural spines present from the fifth presacral vertebra (character 345: 2à1). In some MPTs, Tasmaniosaurus triassicus is recovered at the base of Chasmatosuchinae but this position is not supported by apomorphies. Alternatively, the placement of the chasmatosuchines within Erythrosuchidae is supported by the presence of: posterior cervical, anterior dorsal, and sometimes middle dorsal vertebrae with a thick, mainly vertical tuberosity immediately ventral to the transverse process (character 319: 0à1), anterior-middle and sometimes posterior postaxial cervical vertebrae with distally restricted transverse expansion of the neural spines (not mammillary process) (character 321: 0à1), Cv4 or Cv5 centrum length versus height of anterior articular surface of 1.75–2.08 (character 331: 2à3), anterior and middle postaxial cervical neural spines with an anterior overhang as a result of an anteriorly curved anterior margin of the neural spine (character 343: 0à1), and ninth presacral centrum with a ventral keel (character 892: 0à1). The bootstrap frequencies are very low (<50%) in the non-eucrocopod archosauriform region of the tree.

The analysis under implied weights with k = 10 recovered >500,000 MPTs with a fit of 300.68073, CI of 0.18245, and RI of 0.63761. The analyses with a k = 13 and 15 found 191,835 MPTs (k = 13: fit of 255.32317, CI of 0.18270 and RI of 0.63821; k = 15: fit of 232.26259, CI of 0.18275 and RI of 0.63835). The SCT of the analysis with k = 10 has a topology almost identical to that of the SCT of Analysis 1 under equal weights, but with the placement of UNIPAMPA 684 among the successive sister taxa to the Erythrosuchidae + Eucrocopoda clade rather than within Proterosuchidae (figure S28). Proterosuchidae is represented by a very large polytomy including all its members in the SCT and the iterPCR procotol found that ‘Archosaurus rossicus holotype’ is mainly responsible for this lack of resolution. The a posteriori pruning of this terminal results in a dichotomy between a Proterosuchus and a Chasmatosuchinae clade. The former is composed of Proterosuchus fergusi , Proterosuchus alexanderi, Proterosuchus goweri, FC-DPV 2641 and ‘Blomosuchus georgii holotype’. The base of Chasmatosuchinae is represented by a trichotomy composed of UNIPAMPA 271, Proterosuchus yuani and a clade formed by ‘Chasmatosuchus rossicus holotype’ and a polytomy that includes all the other members of the subfamily (i.e. Jaikosuchus magnus, Gamosaurus lozovskii, Tsylmosuchus spp., UNIPAMPA 750, the Arcadia proterosuchian vertebrae, and ‘Samsarasuchus pamelae reduced’). The placement of Proterosuchus yuani and UNIPAMPA 271 within Chasmatosuchinae is supported by the following synapomorphy in this analysis: posterior cervical, anterior dorsal, and sometimes middle dorsal vertebrae with a thick, mainly vertical tuberosity immediately ventral to the transverse process (character 319: 0à1). Among the successive sister taxa to the Erythrosuchidae + Eucrocopoda clade, the a posteriori pruning of ‘Kalisuchus rewanensis holotype’ and NMQR 3570 resolves a clade composed of Sarmatosuchus otschevi + (Long Reef proterosuchian + UNIPAMPA 684). This clade is also supported by character 319 (0à1), and the group formed by the latter two terminals is supported by the presence of at least some middle and posterior dorsal centra with a single keel on the ventral surface (character 353: 0à2). The bootstrap frequencies in this analysis are very low (<50%) in the non-erythrosuchid, non-eucrocopod archosauriform region of the tree.

The analyses with k = 13 and 15 have SCTs of identical topologies (figures S29 and S30). The base of Archosauriformes has a trichotomy composed of Tasmaniosaurus triassicus, Chasmatosuchinae, and a clade formed by Proterosuchidae and more crownward species. Tasmaniosaurus triassicus is alternatively found among the MPTs as the sister taxon to Archosauriformes, at the base of Chasmatosuchinae, or as the sister taxon to the Chasmatosuchinae + Archosauriformes clade, but none of these placements is supported by apomorphies. The a posteriori pruning of Tasmaniosaurus triassicus resolves Chasmatosuchinae as the sister taxon to Archosauriformes, as was the case in the SRCT of Analysis 6 under equal weights. The apomorphies that support the exclusion of the chasmatosuchines from Archosauriformes are the same as under equal weights. It is worth mentioning that Vonhuenia friedrichi and Antarctanax shackletoni form a clade at the base of Chasmatosuchinae. This relationship is supported by the presence of fifth cervical vertebra to middle dorsal vertebrae with gradual transverse expansion of the distal half of the neural spine, but lacking distinct mammillary processes on the lateral surface of the neural spine (character 320: 2à1). The bootstrap frequencies are very low (<50%) among the non-erythrosuchid, non-eucrocopod archosauriforms in the analyses under implied weights with k = 13 and 15.

p.bold: 4.5. Leaf stability in the phylogenetic analyses

sec.p: The mean of the Leaf Stability Index (LSI) of all the terminals included in Analysis 5 (to the exclusion of Petrolacosaurus kansensis, which was used to root the trees and as a result has a LSI of 1) is 0.84 (standard deviation [sd] = 0.06). All proterosuchids have lower values than the mean of the dataset (LSI = 0.63−0.80, mean = 0.74, sd = 0.07) and this is clearly visible in the plot of LSI against geological time (figure 43a). Nevertheless, Permian–Early Triassic non-proterosuchid archosauromorphs have similarly low values (LSI = 0.66–0.89, mean = 0.78, sd = 0.07) and the two groups do not differ significantly in the phylogenetic ANOVA (pANOVA; p = 1.00) (figure 43c). The plot of LSI against geological time shows that Middle and Late Triassic terminals have generally higher LSI values than older taxa (figure 43a). Indeed, the mean of the LSI of Middle Triassic archosauromorphs is 0.84 (sd = 0.04) and they differ significantly from the LSI values of Permian–Early Triassic non-proterosuchid archosauromorphs (pANOVA p-value = 0.02) (figure 43c). Proterosuchids do not differ significantly from Middle Triassic archosauromorphs (pANOVA p-value = 0.11). However, when all Early Triassic archosauromorphs are compared with those of the Middle Triassic there is a significant difference between their LSI values (pANOVA p-value < 0.01) (figure 43c).

The plot of the amount of missing data of each terminal against geological time does not show a clear concentration of fragmentary terminals in any particular portion of the studied temporal range, but an apparently random distribution of the data (figure 43a). This contrasts with the concentration of the lowest LSI values around the Permo-Triassic boundary. The phylogenetic generalized least squares (pGLS) regression of missing data versus the mean age of the terminals is not significant (p-value = 0.14; R2 = 0.01; figure 43b), nor is the pGLS regression of LSI against geological time (p-value = 0.43; R2 < 0.01). The plot of LSI against missing data shows that the lowest LSI values occur only in terminals with a proportion of missing data >80%, but several other highly fragmentary terminals also have relatively high LSI values (>0.80) (figure 43b). The pANOVA did not find significant differences between the missing data values of proterosuchids, Permian–Early Triassic non-proterosuchid archosauromorphs, and Middle Triassic archosauromorphs; nor between Early Triassic and Middle Triassic archosauromorphs.

The pGLS regression of LSI versus missing data is significant (p-value <0.01), but this model explains a very low amount of variance (R2 = 0.08) (figure 43b). Indeed, the plot of the residuals of this model against geological time is very similar to that of LSI against geological time. Finally, the pGLS regression of LSI versus missing data + geological time finds a significant interaction only with missing data (p-value <0.01) and not with the age of the terminals (p-value = 0.60); the explained variance of this model is very low (R2 = 0.07).

p.bold: as a new genus and species of proterosuchid

sec.p: Following the discovery of proterosuchids in Lower Triassic beds in South Africa and China, the proterosuchid remains from the Panchet Formation were generally considered as co-generic with those of the above-mentioned countries, being assigned to either Proterosuchus or “Chasmatosaurus” [37,44–46,71–74]. The new anatomical information provided here for the Panchet proterosuchid Samsarasuchus pamelae has shown multiple differences with the South African and Chinese proterosuchids, including: the presence of a foramen on the medial wall of the quadrate foramen; postzygapophyses well-developed posteriorly, forming a distinct notch with the posterior margin of the neural spine, and a dorsally convex dorsal margin of the neural spine in the axis; a diagonal ridge that reaches the prezygapophysis on the lateral surface of the neural arch of Cv3–Cv8; a strongly laterally developed longitudinal shelf projecting posteriorly from the base of the diapophysis and a vertical or posterodorsally canted neural spine in Cv4–Cv6; a posteriorly expanded neural spine in Cv4–Cv8; an anteriorly curved anterior margin and distally restricted transverse expansion of the neural spine in anterior-middle cervical vertebrae; a longitudinal keel on the ventral surface of the centrum in Cv9; a prezygodiapophyseal lamina in posterior cervical and anterior dorsal vertebrae; a posterior centrodiapophyseal lamina in anterior dorsal vertebrae; a longitudinal keel on the ventral surface of the middle dorsal centra; a very deep and well defined fossa lateral to the base of the neural spine in anterior caudal vertebrae; and an entepicondyle of the distal end of the humerus poorly projected from the level of the shaft. Thus, all these character states demonstrate that the anatomy of Samsarasuchus pamelae is considerably different from that of the genus Proterosuchus than previously assumed.

Ezcurra [18] discussed that the proterosuchid vertebrae from the Panchet Formation (now forming part of the hypodigm of Samsarasuchus pamelae) differed from those of the Russian Chasmatosuchus rossicus, Jaikosuchus magnus, Tsylmosuchus samariensis, and “Gamosaurus lozovskii” in the absence of a shelf-like, laterally flaring thick tuberosity projected posteriorly from the base of the diapophysis along the lateral surface of the centrum. This statement was based on a vertebra here interpreted as a Cv3 (GSI 2111) and an anterior dorsal vertebra (GSI 2116), which both belong to vertebral regions that lack such a shelf-like tuberosity in Samsarasuchus pamelae. By contrast, the specimens studied here allowed us to recognize the presence of this character state in Samsarasuchus pamelae, which is also present in the four species mentioned above, as well as in the Russian Tsylmosuchus jakovlevi and the Arcadia proterosuchian vertebrae. When Samsarasuchus pamelae is compared to these members of Chasmatosuchinae there are multiple differences with known species. For example, the anterior−middle cervical vertebrae of Samsarasuchus pamelae are proportionally shorter (centrum length versus centrum anterior height <2.0) than those of Tsylmosuchus spp. and the neural spines are proportionally shorter (neural spine height versus posterior articular surface of centrum height <1.4) than those of Tsylmosuchus spp., Chasmatosuchus rossicus , Jaikosuchus magnus, and UNIPAMPA 750 (figure 44). In addition, an anterior cervical vertebra that has been referred to “Blomosuchus georgii” and which is here considered probably referable to Vonhuenia friedrichi (PIN 1025/420) lacks the strongly laterally developed, wing-like tuberosity on the lateral surface of the centrum present in Samsarasuchus pamelae and other chasmatosuchines. Beyond these differences, the holotype of Samsarasuchus pamelae differs from other Permo-Triassic archosauromorphs in the presence of an autapomorphic posteriormost cervical vertebra (Cv9) with two pairs of mammillary processes on the neural spine and a dorsolaterally oriented anterior pair of mammillary processes. This evidence supports the proposal that the proterosuchid from the Panchet Formation represents a distinct species.

The results of the phylogenetic analyses further support the distinction between Samsarasuchus pamelae and other proterosuchids (figure 41 b,c). The Indian taxon is recovered outside of the genus Proterosuchus and outside the more deeply nested chasmatosuchines. This phylogenetic arrangement bolsters the erection of a new genus for the Panchet proterosuchid.
